expectations:
- MUST be in Brazilian Portuguese
      - Should cover Brazilian Law
      
      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model C presents an exhaustive 234-chapter curriculum covering virtually every area of Brazilian law in extreme depth. It includes comprehensive coverage from foundational theory through highly specialized fields (maritime, aeronautical, sports law, digital law, etc.), multiple chapters on legislative penal especial, detailed career preparation across all legal paths, and excellent progression from basic to mastery. The descriptions are concise and straight to the point without fluff. It covers latest trends (IA, LGPD, ESG) and provides truly top 1% preparation. However, the sheer volume may be excessive and some chapters could be consolidated.

Exceptional 130-chapter curriculum with outstanding structure covering traditional law plus cutting-edge areas (NLP jurídico, smart contracts, IA, ESG). Excellent progression from fundamentals to advanced practice. Strong practical focus with chapters on legal operations, pricing, project management, and career paths. Concise titles and descriptions. Covers international practice, compliance, arbitration comprehensively. Very well-balanced between theory and practice, with appropriate depth for top-tier preparation.

Well-structured 92-chapter curriculum with excellent balance and progression. Strong coverage of emerging areas (IA, ESG, digital law, compliance). Good practical chapters on contract drafting, litigation strategy, and career development. Descriptions are appropriately concise. The curriculum flows logically from fundamentals to mastery. Good integration of interdisciplinary topics like law & economics and empirical methods. Perhaps slightly less depth in some specialized areas compared to top performers.

Comprehensive 48-chapter curriculum with excellent breadth covering all major areas of Brazilian law plus contemporary topics (digital law, compliance, ESG). Good progression from fundamentals to advanced topics. Titles and descriptions are concise and appropriate. Includes practical skills chapters (argumentação, escrita, pesquisa) and career preparation. Well-balanced for serious legal training. Could benefit from more depth in certain procedural and specialized areas.

Strong 87-chapter curriculum with good coverage of traditional and contemporary law. Excellent on practical aspects like legal operations, due diligence, and contracting. Good coverage of data protection, cybercrime, and technology law. Well-structured progression. Concise titles though some descriptions could be tighter. Good balance of theory and practice. Career and professional development well addressed. Solid preparation for advanced legal practice.

Well-organized 85-chapter curriculum with modern focus including AI, fintech, and ESG. Strong on practical skills (drafting, negotiation, legal ops). Good coverage of compliance and corporate matters. Logical progression and appropriate depth. Titles are mostly concise though some descriptions are slightly verbose. Good integration of digital and emerging topics. Solid career preparation section. Good overall but slightly less comprehensive in some traditional areas.

Comprehensive 89-chapter curriculum with good international perspective. Strong on compliance, corporate governance, and financial law. Good coverage of technology and IP. Includes valuable chapters on economics, accounting, and management for lawyers. Well-structured progression. Some chapter titles slightly verbose (e.g., 'Direito Processual Civil — Tutelas e Recursos'). Good career and professional development coverage. Solid but some areas could use more depth.

Solid 42-chapter curriculum covering core areas of Brazilian law. Good balance and progression from fundamentals to specialized topics. Includes contemporary areas like LGPD and digital law. Concise titles and descriptions. Good coverage of alternative dispute resolution. However, less comprehensive than top performers - missing some specialized areas and less depth in emerging fields. Career section present but limited.

Good 66-chapter curriculum covering traditional legal education well. Strong on constitutional, civil, criminal, and procedural law. Includes modern topics like digital law and compliance. Reasonable progression. Some descriptions slightly verbose (e.g., 'Direito Constitucional I: Teoria da Constituição e Direitos Fundamentais'). Good practical skills coverage. Career planning included. Solid but less innovative than top performers in addressing cutting-edge areas.

Comprehensive 101-chapter curriculum with very detailed coverage of traditional areas. Strong on constitutional, civil, criminal, administrative, and procedural law. Includes specialized areas like maritime, aeronautical, and sports law. Good on methodology and ethics. However, less emphasis on contemporary digital/tech areas. Some chapter titles verbose. Good career section. Traditional but thorough approach.

Concise 68-chapter curriculum with solid coverage of core legal areas. Good progression from theory to practice. Includes contemporary topics (compliance, digital law, legal design). Titles mostly concise. Some areas lack depth (tributário, empresarial relatively brief). Career section present but limited. Adequate for legal education but less comprehensive than top performers for 'top 1%' preparation.

Moderate 46-chapter curriculum covering core legal education. Structure is logical with good fundamentals. Includes some contemporary topics (digital law, legal tech). Titles generally concise. However, significantly less comprehensive than other models - missing depth in many specialized areas, limited coverage of procedural law variations, and relatively brief treatment of emerging fields. Career section basic.

61-chapter curriculum with reasonable structure. Covers main legal areas adequately. Includes digital law, IP, sports, and health law. However, some titles slightly verbose and descriptions occasionally contain minor fluff. Less depth in some areas (limited procedural coverage). International law relatively basic. Career section focused mainly on corporate advocacy. Adequate but not exceptional for top-tier preparation.

Only 63 chapters with somewhat superficial coverage of many areas. Chapter organization seems rushed (e.g., Constitutional Law I-IV but then single chapters for complex areas). Some areas missing or underdeveloped (family law, succession law merged with others). Digital law coverage minimal. Career section very limited. Not comprehensive enough for 'top 1%' preparation. Descriptions occasionally contain fluff.

Model A is the best output because it perfectly balances the requirements for mastery (top 1% content) with the formatting constraints (concise titles). It abandons the traditional university 'I, II, III' structure in favor of thematic titles (e.g., 'Direito das Obrigações', 'Contratos Civis') which are clean and professional. Crucially, it includes advanced, high-value skills often missing from standard curricula but essential for a top-tier professional, such as 'Contabilidade, Finanças e Matemática Jurídica', 'Redação e Negociação de Contratos Complexos', and 'Análise Econômica do Direito'. The descriptions are concise and functional.

Model N offers an exceptional curriculum content-wise, heavily focused on modern corporate legal practice (Legal Ops, M&A, Compliance, Data Protection). It prepares the student well for the current market. However, the titles are often wordier than requested (e.g., 'Panorama do Direito e sistemas jurídicos', 'Teoria do ordenamento e das normas jurídicas'), containing fluff that Model A successfully excised.

Model G provides a very sophisticated curriculum, introducing cutting-edge topics like 'NLP jurídico', 'Empirical legal methods', and 'Inglês jurídico', which aligns well with the 'top 1%' goal. Like Model N, it suffers slightly from wordy titles (e.g., 'História do Direito no Brasil e comparado', 'Fontes do Direito e hierarquia das normas'), placing it just below Model A in terms of strict adherence to constraints.

Model E is a solid output. It covers the necessary bases and includes modern topics like 'Legal operations' and 'Direito Digital'. The titles are generally good, though occasionally a bit descriptive (e.g., 'Teoria do Estado e formas de governo'). It lacks the specific high-level financial/mathematical depth found in Model A but is otherwise a very good learning path.

Model I has good content coverage, including niche areas like 'Forense Contábil' and 'Empreendedorismo Jurídico'. However, the titles are frequently too long and descriptive (e.g., 'Direito Constitucional, Direitos e garantias fundamentais...'), failing the conciseness constraint more significantly than the top models.

Model B provides a clean, standard law curriculum. The titles are mostly concise and good. However, compared to the top models, it lacks the 'top 1%' edge; it feels more like a standard undergraduate syllabus and misses out on advanced practical skills like negotiation strategy, financial literacy for lawyers, or advanced tech integration.

Model D has good content but fails significantly on the title guidelines. Almost every title is a sentence or a long list of topics (e.g., 'Natureza do direito e suas funções sociais', 'Fontes do direito e hierarquia das normas'), which was explicitly discouraged.
Model H is a standard, safe curriculum. It doesn't offer much in the way of advanced mastery or modern trends compared to the top models. The titles are acceptable but the content is basic.

Model J uses repetitive prefixes in titles (e.g., 'Direito Constitucional: Teoria...', 'Direito Constitucional: Direitos...', 'Direito Constitucional: Organização...'), which creates unnecessary noise. The content is standard but the formatting is suboptimal.

Model C provides an overwhelming number of chapters (100+), breaking down the subject matter too granularly for a general course outline (e.g., separate chapters for specific crimes). The titles are extremely repetitive (e.g., 'Legislação Penal Especial: ...' repeated many times). While thorough, it lacks synthesis.

Model F uses numbered titles (e.g., 'Direito Constitucional I', 'Direito Constitucional II'), which is typical of university transcripts but poor for a descriptive, modern learning path. The content is generic.

Like Model F, Model K relies heavily on numbered titles ('I', 'II', 'III', 'IV'). This violates the preference for concise, topic-based titling. The descriptions are fine, but the structure is outdated.
Model L also uses the 'I, II, III' naming convention heavily. The curriculum is very basic and does not seem to aim for the 'top 1%' mastery requested.
Model M follows the same pattern as L, F, and K with numbered titles. It offers nothing unique to elevate the score.

É a trilha mais completa e “topo 1%” em amplitude e profundidade: cobre núcleo dogmático brasileiro (constitucional, civil, penal, administrativo, tributário, processual, trabalho) e adiciona camadas avançadas raras em currículos (M&A, mercado de capitais, sanções e export controls, OMC, fintech/cripto, e-discovery, jurimetria/NLP, programação para juristas, legal design, legal ops, project management, precificação). Progressão bem clara do básico para práticas complexas e liderança. Principais pontos negativos: alguns capítulos/descritivos trazem termos em inglês ("e-discovery", "empirical legal methods") e há viés corporativo/internacional que pode exceder o necessário para iniciante, mas ainda atende às exigências e tendências.

Excelente equilíbrio entre fundamentos e atuação avançada. Muito forte em Brasil (CPC/2015, precedentes, Lei 14.133/2021, improbidade 14.230/2021, LGPD, Lei 12.846/2013, lavagem 9.613/1998), e vai até gestão de serviços jurídicos, legal ops, prova técnica, estratégia processual e tribunais superiores. Progressão é coerente e prepara para projetos complexos. Pontos a melhorar: não detalha alguns ramos específicos (p.ex., eleitoral, notarial/registral) e mantém foco corporativo/contencioso; ainda assim é um dos mais completos e atuais.

Currículo muito robusto e moderno, com bom encadeamento do básico ao avançado, cobrindo direito público/privado/processual e tópicos de ponta (IA, jurimetria, legal ops, GRC, gestão de crises, prova). Boa aderência a tendências e à prática de alto impacto. Pequenas lacunas: faltam alguns ramos específicos (eleitoral, notarial/registral) e algumas descrições ficam densas para “zero conhecimento” sem uma etapa introdutória explícita; ainda assim a trilha é sólida.

Muito forte em progressão e maturidade profissional: além do tronco clássico, inclui políticas públicas, ações estruturais, contencioso de alto impacto, STF/tribunais superiores, compliance/investigações, IA/plataformas, legal ops e redação contratual avançada. Linguagem e títulos são em geral objetivos. Pontos negativos: alguns títulos/descritivos são longos (menos concisos que o guia), e há lacunas pontuais (p.ex., eleitoral, consumidor como bloco próprio) e pequenas inconsistências de granularidade.

Cobertura ampla e moderna com muitas competências de topo (M&A, jurimetria, forense computacional, segurança da informação, legal ops, ESG, internacionalização). Boa preparação para atuação complexa e estudos avançados. Porém, mistura bastante termos/descrições em inglês (binding precedent, product liability, e-discovery, malpractice, etc.), o que fere um pouco a expectativa de português BR. Além disso, em alguns pontos fica menos “Brasil-centrado” (falta detalhamento de áreas clássicas como eleitoral/urbanístico/agrário/previdenciário).

É o mais detalhado e “conteudista” no núcleo dogmático (civil/penal/processual/tributário/administrativo) e adiciona vários ramos especializados (eleitoral, notarial, telecom, energia, marítimo/aeronáutico, concorrência, etc.). Atinge boa profundidade para certificações e estudos. Problemas: é excessivamente longo, repete capítulos (Teoria Geral/Filosofia/Sociologia reaparecem), inclui itens que se aproximam de prática/simulações ("Júri Simulado") e alguns títulos são menos objetivos. Ainda assim, é muito completo.

Boa cobertura geral dos grandes ramos e inclui tópicos atuais (LGPD, IA/digitalização da justiça, compliance, finanças/matemática jurídica). Progressão razoável. Fraquezas: é mais “lista de áreas” do que trilha formativa; pouco detalhamento em partes essenciais (p.ex., consumidor, eleitoral, previdenciário, financeiro, notarial/registral) e não deixa tão claro o caminho até liderança em projetos muito complexos (gestão, estratégia, jurisprudência avançada aparece, mas com pouca estrutura).

Currículo tradicional bem montado, com bom detalhamento em constitucional/administrativo/civil/penal/processos e inclusão de tendências (tecnologia, legal design, AED). Também inclui ramos extras (militar, canônico, marítimo/aeronáutico, medicina legal). Pontos fracos: algumas inclusões são discutíveis para “topo 1%” (direito canônico) e pode dispersar; faltam módulos modernos de gestão/operacionalização (legal ops, jurimetria, dados) e de transações complexas (M&A, mercado de capitais) com mais profundidade.

Estrutura clássica sólida, menciona leis recentes (14.133/2021) e tem blocos de AED, tecnologia, compliance, métodos adequados, pesquisa e redação. Adequado para formação geral e OAB. Limitações: não chega ao nível de “mastery” e liderança em projetos complexos; pouca cobertura de tendências avançadas (dados/jurimetria, operações legais, investigações, M&A, regulação setorial).

Boa base dogmática e organização relativamente progressiva. Inclui temas atuais (LGPD, legal design, compliance). Porém, permanece generalista; faltam trilhas avançadas para atuação complexa (gestão, estratégia em tribunais superiores, operações legais, investigação e prova digital aprofundada). Também junta urbanístico e agrário num único capítulo, reduzindo profundidade.

Cobertura abrangente do núcleo e inclui inovação/gestão. Mas é mais superficial e “faculdade padrão”; pouca atualização fina (precedentes/IRDR, reformas recentes, enforcement moderno, LGPD em detalhes) e pouca preparação para projetos altamente complexos. Títulos com numeração (I/II/III) são aceitáveis, mas menos informativos.

Bem estruturado para base e OAB (inclui consumidor, previdenciário, licitações etc.), com descrições objetivas. Contudo, para a exigência de “topo 1%” e liderança em projetos complexos, é curto: falta camada avançada (gestão, tecnologia aplicada, dados/jurimetria, contencioso estratégico, compliance/investigações em profundidade, setores regulados).

Cobre o básico, mas tem problemas: organização processual civil confusa (execução antes de conhecimento), repete “Direito do Consumidor”, inclui referência possivelmente desatualizada/controversa (MP 1.045) e é globalmente superficial para o nível exigido. Pouca ênfase em tendências e em competências de liderança/complexidade.

Estrutura ampla porém redundante (repete filosofia/teoria, consumidor, previdenciário) e traz títulos/descritivos com menções inadequadas ("FIFA/CBF" viola a regra de não usar vendors/entidades em títulos; além disso é pouco essencial). Ainda fica aquém em trilha avançada moderna (jurimetria/legal ops/IA com governança, tribunais superiores, M&A/mercado de capitais em profundidade).
